title: Does Godel's incompleteness theorem prove that God must exist? - Quora

response.answer_text: Question originally answered: Does Godel's incompleteness theorem prove that God must exist?  Let’s first start off by pointing out that it’s not ‘Gödel’s incompleteness theorem’, rather it is ‘Gödel’s incompleteness theorems’. Then let’s take a look at what it even is that they[1] say: Any effective logic, capable of interpreting Robinson Arithmetic, must eitherHave a proposition [math]{\sf P}[/math], which is both provable and disprovable (i.e. be syntactically inconsistent), orHave a proposition [math]{\sf P}[/math], which is neither provable nor disprovable (i.e. be syntactically incomplete)Any effective logic, capable of interpreting Robinson Arithmetic, if it satisfies 1b above, (i.e. is syntactically consistent and therefore syntactically incomplete), has among its undecidable propositions, the proposition that expresses its own consistency.Now, since these are rather precise assertions, that put no further restrictions on the language of the logic than that they can express Robinson Arithmetic and be effective (itself a precisely defined concept, which basically amounts to being able to enumerate all possible proofs of the logic, in some specific order), one must ask one’s self how we could even come to the conclusion that we could even express the proposition that ‘God exists’, which is of course a necessary precondition for further reasoning on that proposition and its provability/disprovability. And if we cannot even express that proposition, than how, in God’s name (invocation of a deity intended), can we ever come to the conclusion that God exists. Furthermore, even if we could express that proposition, how does the OP know that this proposition even is an undecidable proposition as the first theorem guarantees to exist. If the proposition is provable, then it is not undecidable and one questions the relevance of the incompleteness theorems in the first place. And if it is an undecidable proposition such as the first theorem guarantees to exist, than you should consider the fact that any such logic, if it is a first order logic, by another of Gödel’s theorems, the completeness theorem[2], is semantically complete. That is to say, that any such logic can prove all propositions that are necessarily true in all models of the logic. Therefore, from the fact that ‘God exists’, would be an expressible and undecidable proposition, it follows that ‘God exists’, is not necessarily true at all, otherwise it would be provable (by the completeness theorem). Perhaps more explicitly, the proposition ‘God exists’, is at best contingently true, true in some worlds and not in others. And since we do not know whether or not our world is even sufficiently similar to any of these models worlds, where we already have at most a contingently true proposition, we can conclude nothing at all about whether or not God exists in reality. Logic cannot prove anything at all about reality.  Now, lest you think that when you reason about a logic, you are reasoning outside of the logic, I would hasten to point out that you might be reasoning outside of the object logic you are looking at, but you are not reasoning outside of any logic at all. Specifically, you are still reasoning inside of the logic you are using to even speak about your object logic (one to which the incompleteness theorems apply), the meta-logic, and it’s language. And, curiously enough, a meta-logic is still just a logic! It is a logic that has as its domain of discourse, propositions as strings of symbols, deductions as a structure consisting of applications of inference rules to object propositions. It features it own propositions as well, the meta-propositions, which are built up from meta-symbols, such as [math]\vdash_{\mathfrak{L}}[/math], which represents the notion of derivability of an object proposition from some collection of object propositions. An example of such a meta-proposition would be the incompleteness theorems themselves. If [math]\mathfrak{L}[/math] is the class of all logics satisfying the prerequisites of the incompleteness theorem and if [math]\mathfrak{l} \in \mathfrak{L}[/math], is such a logic then we have the first incomplete theorem expressed as: [math]\forall \mathfrak{l} \in \mathfrak{L}. \mathrm{SynInconsistent}(\mathfrak{l}) \lor \mathrm{SynIncomplete}(\mathfrak{l})[/math]where [math]\mathrm{SynInconsistent}(\mathfrak{l}) \overset{\text{def}}{\iff} \exists {\sf P} \in \mathrm{Language}(\mathfrak{l}). \vdash_{\mathfrak{l}} {\sf P} \land \vdash_{\mathfrak{l}} {\sf \lnot P}[/math][math]\mathrm{SynIncomplete}(\mathfrak{l}) \overset{\text{def}}{\iff} \exists {\sf P} \in \mathrm{Language}(\mathfrak{l}). \not \vdash_{\mathfrak{l}} {\sf P} \land \not \vdash_{\mathfrak{l}} {\sf \lnot P}[/math]We are never reasoning outside of some logic. This false popular idea that we can somehow recognise a necessary truth of logic, by ‘stepping outside’ of logic, is simply non-sense. We step outside of one logic logic straight inside of another, to which the incompleteness theorems quite possibly also apply, and in fact must, since use enumeration over proofs of the object logic.  All of the above is utterly ignoring the fact the incompleteness theorems are not even about truth of propositions at all, but are about provability of propositions. They are a computational result on the computability of strings from strings. These strings need not even be interpreted as ‘statements on models’. The incompleteness theorems are independent of any interpretation of the language of the logic. Perhaps more clearly, the proposition ‘God exists’, is just a string of symbols without any meaning at all, sans an interpretation, and yet the incompleteness theorems would still apply.  The theorems have no theological relevance at all. Footnotes[1] Gödel's incompleteness theorems - Wikipedia[2] Gödel's completeness theorem - Wikipedia

I presume this question is confusing Gödel’s incompleteness theorems[1], which point out that we cannot create a complete and self consistent inductive model of logic or mathematics, at least not in the form that Bertrand Russel was attempting prior to Gödel publishing his theorems, with Gödel’s ontological “proof” of God[2], which used symbolic statements to prove that a sequence of logical statements in that particular symbolic language led to the inevitability of another symbolic statement. Here is his proof: [math]{\displaystyle {\begin{array}{rl}{\text{Ax. 1.}}&\left(P(\varphi )\;\wedge \;\Box \;\forall x(\varphi (x)\Rightarrow \psi (x))\right)\;\Rightarrow \;P(\psi )\\{\text{Ax. 2.}}&P(\neg \varphi )\;\Leftrightarrow \;\neg P(\varphi )\\{\text{Th. 1.}}&P(\varphi )\;\Rightarrow \;\Diamond \;\exists x\;\varphi (x)\\{\text{Df. 1.}}&G(x)\;\Leftrightarrow \;\forall \varphi (P(\varphi )\Rightarrow \varphi (x))\\{\text{Ax. 3.}}&P(G)\\{\text{Th. 2.}}&\Diamond \;\exists x\;G(x)\\{\text{Df. 2.}}&\varphi {\text{ ess }}x\;\Leftrightarrow \;\varphi (x)\wedge \forall \psi \left(\psi (x)\Rightarrow \Box \;\forall y(\varphi (y)\Rightarrow \psi (y))\right)\\{\text{Ax. 4.}}&P(\varphi )\;\Rightarrow \;\Box \;P(\varphi )\\{\text{Th. 3.}}&G(x)\;\Rightarrow \;G{\text{ ess }}x\\{\text{Df. 3.}}&E(x)\;\Leftrightarrow \;\forall \varphi (\varphi {\text{ ess }}x\Rightarrow \Box \;\exists y\;\varphi (y))\\{\text{Ax. 5.}}&P(E)\\{\text{Th. 4.}}&\Box \;\exists x\;G(x)\end{array}}}[/math] God appears to be [math]G(x)[/math]. Apparently, it is essentially a restatement of the ontological argument that there is a single greatest thing in the universe, which we then just simply declare to be God. If that makes any sense to you, then you are either smarter or dumber than I am, or you are just emotionally bound in a way that I am not to the idea that God is logical and is somehow subject to logical proofs. If it is the latter, there is always the Babel fish to dissuade you.  Footnotes[1] Gödel's incompleteness theorems - Wikipedia[2] Gödel's ontological proof - Wikipedia

If the theorem you are talking about is one in which the name Godel, when spelled with two fewer letters at the end, is “incomplete” then yes. Otherwise, no, that’s silly. Even if (and we’ll talk about that in a moment) you somehow get from Godel’s incompleteness theorem to “therefore some god exists” there’s nothing there to indicate which deity. Mankind CURRENTLY worships tens of millions of gods, over four thousand religions (some with multiple gods, some with LOTS of gods, which is how we get from four thousand to tens of millions) and for that matter, unknown numbers have been worshiped in the past and are now forgotten, and there’s no reason to think we’ve exhausted all possible notions of gods, any one of THOSE might be “the real god/s” But let’s discuss the notion that the incompleteness theorem proves SOME god exists. The theorem states that no mathematical system that is sufficiently interesting can be complete. In short, there will be statements which are unprovable. Did you see any hint of a god in there? No? Me either.

Hawking and others lamented about Godel’s incompleteness theorem because Hawking believed it showed there can never be a theory of everything. Godel’s incompleteness and ontological proof shows why he was a Platonist. In other words, attributes like goodness are infinite and exists outside of the physical realm. Godel’s Incompleteness is clear proof of a metaphysical reality that exists outside of physical reality. This metaphysical reality is necessary while we’re contingent. This closely ties into the qualia space of Giulio Tononi. In other words, any system described by mathematics will be incomplete and will need to appeal to an unprovable truth outside of that system. Godel’s incompleteness theorem says this: "Any consistent formal system F within which a certain amount of elementary arithmetic can be carried out is incomplete; i.e., there are statements of the language of F which can neither be proved nor disproved in F." WOW!! If you look at the universe, which is described by mathematics, then according to Godel, there are things about the universe that can’t be proven by anything in the universe. So at some point the physical universe ends(Planck’s constant) and this metaphysical reality begins(Tononi’s Qualia Space, Quantum mind?).

Godel’s incompleteness theorem is about mathematics and formal systems. It does not really “prove” anything “real”. As I understand it, it is akin to saying that you can’t have a language without defining a basic set of words first, that cannot be defined in that same language. In other words, that every dictionary relies on some words that you must know the meaning of but that can’t be defined in the dictionary itself. I can’t see how this is proof of God (or any gods, or anything at all besides formal systems).

Gödel’s incompleteness theorem has absolutely nothing to do with the existence of gods. Gods are not axiomatic first-order theories in which number theory can be expressed. Whatever gods are, they don’t seem to be theories with axioms in a first-order language.

Does Godel's incompleteness theorem prove that God must exist? I doubt it. But to the extent that it “proves” anything at all, it surely must equally “prove” thousands of other creator gods. So either you have successfully “proved” thousands of gods or you have nothing useful here. Pick one.

No. Mathematics and logical statements don’t deal with reality - only abstractions. It’s not possible to answer any question about existence using logic or mathematics. We can, if we are fortunate, find mathematics that fits reality, but we can’t make reality from mathematics.

Q: Does Godel's incompleteness theorem prove that God must exist? A2A A: No, it proves that there are some things we are ignorant of. The fact that theists confuse ignorance with proof speaks volumes.
“Does Godel's incompleteness theorem prove that God must exist?” Yes, as much as it can prove that unicorns and fairies must exist.
Philosophy preaches to intended audiences, and proves little. Seek God in your heart. Seek God in theology. Seek God in science and mathematics. Follow me and seek your answers there.
No. It proves that there are an infinite number of undecidable propositions in formal logic.
